document.title: How to spot fake bank texts in 30 seconds
document.description: Learn the quick red flags that separate real bank alerts from scam texts trying to steal your money.

body.raw:
# How to spot fake bank texts in 30 seconds

Bank scams via text message are one of the most common ways scammers try to trick people. But there's a simple way to check if a text is really from your bank.

## Step 1: Check the sender

Real banks never text from random numbers. They use official sender IDs like "Chase" or "Bank of America". If it's from a weird number like +1234567890, it's probably fake.

## Step 2: Look for urgency

Scammers create panic: "Your account is locked!" or "Action required in 15 minutes!" Real banks give you time and don't threaten immediate closure.

## Step 3: Never click links in texts

Legitimate banks won't ask you to click links in texts to "verify" or "unlock" your account. They direct you to use their official app or website.

## What to do instead

If you're worried about your account, open your bank's official app or call the number on the back of your card. Don't use any numbers from the suspicious text.

Remember: Your bank already has your information. They don't need you to "confirm" anything via text.

document.title: New USPS delivery scam: what to do
document.description: A new scam impersonates USPS delivery notifications. Here's how to spot it and protect yourself.

body.raw:
# New USPS delivery scam: what to do

Scammers are now pretending to be USPS with fake delivery notifications. They claim you have a package that requires "redelivery fees" or "customs clearance."

## What the scam looks like

- Text or email saying: "Your package from Amazon/ebay/etc is held at the post office"
- Asks you to pay a small fee ($10-50) to "release" the package
- Provides a link to pay or a phone number to call
- Creates urgency: "Pay within 24 hours or package returns to sender"

## Why it's dangerous

USPS never asks for payment via text or email for standard deliveries. They also don't hold packages for "customs clearance" on domestic mail.

## What to do

1. **Don't click any links** in the message
2. **Don't call numbers** provided in the message
3. Check your actual USPS account at usps.com
4. If you were expecting a package, contact USPS directly using the number on their official website

## Real USPS communications

- Come from official @usps.com email addresses
- Never ask for payment via unofficial channels
- Provide tracking numbers you can verify on usps.com

Stay safe: When in doubt, go directly to the official website or app.

document.title: Three questions to ask before you click
document.description: A simple checklist to run through before clicking any link in an email or text message.

body.raw:
# Three questions to ask before you click

Links in emails and texts can lead to dangerous websites. But you don't need to be a tech expert to stay safe. Just ask yourself these three questions.

## 1. Did I expect this message?

If you get an unexpected email about "your account" or "a package delivery," be suspicious. Legitimate companies don't send random alerts. If it's about something you actually ordered or have an account for, check your official account first.

## 2. Does the link match the company?

Hover over (don't click) the link. Does the URL match the company's official website? For example:
- Real: amazon.com/returns
- Fake: amaz0n-support.com/update

Scammers use similar-looking domains to trick you.

## 3. Does it create urgency or fear?

Messages that say "Act now or lose access!" or "Your account will be suspended!" are red flags. Real companies give you time and don't threaten immediate consequences.

## Safe alternatives

Instead of clicking suspicious links:
- Type the company's website address directly into your browser
- Use their official app
- Call them using a number from their official website (not from the message)

## Bonus tip

If something feels off, it probably is. Trust your instincts and take the safe route.
